title: Stored XSS in drive.uber.com WordPress admin panel
vulnerability_information:
There is another bug in the All In One Event Calendar plugin used on *drive.uber.com*. An attacker can inject arbitrary JavaScript in the administrative Dashboard of WordPress. The script would be evaluated under administrator privileges (as only logged-in administrators can view the Dashboard). Such script can use AJAX calls to achieve a server-side compromise unless some kind of special protections are in place.

The script can be injected by causing an error condition in the calendar plugin. One way to trigger an error is described below. Whenever this happens, the plugin disables itself and places an error message "banner" in the administrative Dashboard and shows it to any administrator who logs on afterwards.

The error details can be manipulated by the attacker and special HTML characters aren't filtered. The error message includes e.g. the URL which triggered the error, which is controllable by the attacker.

#Reproducing#

The attack requires sending a malformed HTTP request *without* encoding special characters in the URL. Therefore this can't be done with a normal web browser. For example a PERL script like this produces the request:
~~~~perl
#!/usr/bin/perl
open(NC,"|openssl s_client -connect drive.uber.com:443 -quiet") || die;
print NC "GET /oh/?ai1ec_js_widget=ai1ec_agenda_widget&render=true&events_per_page=$%&xss=<svg/onload=alert(/stored-xss/.source)>\r\n";
 HTTP/1.1\r\n";
print NC "Host: drive.uber.com\r\n";
print NC "\r\n";
close(NC);
~~~~
The HTTP response is a redirect back to the "front page", meaning the plugin couldn't render the calendar JSON data as supposed, but encountered an error condition.

Reproducing this of course requires that the plugin is reactivated (it's is currently disabled because I tested this).

Next, when an administrator logs on the system and is presented with the WordPress Dashboard, they should get an alert box, showing that the attacker-supplied JavaScript has been stored in the Dashboard.

Injecting another code won't work until the plugin is reactivated.

#Details#

The error in this case is an invalid format string in an SQL query, caused by the malformed *events_per_page* parameter. The XSS payload is included later in the URL above and gets included in the error message.

I have tested this bug on a local test server running WordPress and the All In One Event Calendar plugin. The difference is that instead of nginx my test server runs Apache. This, or other aspects of your server architecture *might* introduce differences in URL encoding etc. which could prevent the example from working (I'll test with nginx later).

#Impact#

Instead of showing an alert box, the script could use AJAX functions to e.g. create a new administrator user with a known password, or write arbitrary PHP code on the server via the plugin or theme editors. I've referred to such demonstrations in my previous reports.

#Fix#

I haven't reported this to the plugin author yet. One way to protect against this is to comment out the error detail generation in the file wp-content/plugins/all-in-one-event-calendar/lib/exception/handler.php, end of file (not tested).

activities.message: As a status update on this one, we are working to get the proper accounts for our Wordpress instances. Still working on validating this!
Closing this as `Resolved` since we killed this plugin in response to another bug reported by you.

Thanks @jouko we are rewarding 2,000$ for this one due to it not being in any of our data centers (so there isn't any risk of our user data being stolen via this issue). This is also more of an addition to your previous payout for the other issue reported in the plugin than it is a separate bounty (one fix usually is one payout). That being said, awesome find and we appreciate you participating in this program!

For bug #125441 you paid $3000 as stated in your Bounty Payout Range "because our policy previously didn't make it clear the the stated amounts were maximums." Now you pay $2000 instead of $10000 for an RCE - even though the policy didn't make clear the stated amount were maximums. The policy also does not state that finding several bugs in the same software package will be penalized by lowering or even removing bounties for critical issues. This unwritten policy incentivizes **not** reporting bugs; in order to get paid for your work, you have to tactically withhold some bugs and choose which one to report and in which order. This doesn't seem to make sense and is also quite disappointing as someone who spent several hours a day for two weeks working for your program.

Also it might be a good idea to mention the requirement that the bugs exist on one of your data centers, and specify what these centers are. The current policy says "Critical issues ($10,000) - Remote code execution on a production server." I understood you agreed this was a remote code execution on a production server, and on the most important *.uber.com domain in scope. Still, you value this bug less than a trivial reflected XSS. As the policy reads now it's very misleading. Instead of introducing these unwritten rules afterwards, it would seem more appropriate to pay according to the stated policy, under which I expected to be working.

Hey @jouko sorry for the confusion. The reason why this was paid out the way it was is due to this not having a high risk of exposing any of our user data (since it was in a blog site). We do impact-based rewarding on all of our submissions, the impact being "how much of a risk is this to our user base?". Since the bug you found was in our Wordpress instance which is in WPEngine it posed less risk to our user base (since it didn't occur in our production data-centers). 

>The policy also does not state that finding several bugs in the same software package will be penalized by lowering or even removing bounties for critical issues. This unwritten policy incentivizes not reporting bugs; in order to get paid for your work, you have to tactically withhold some bugs and choose which one to report and in which order.

This is a fair point, however in this case withholding the bug information would've led to us removing the plugin anyways. Which would've removed the problem etc. We can discuss this further internally as I do think you have a good point here.

I will get back to you on this soon! Thanks.

Hi @jouko - We will be keeping this bounty the same. 

The payout ranges and amounts on our page we put up to give rough guidance on how we think about valuing issues. Ultimately it isat our discretion on how to reward an issue and as I am sure you would  agree, an xss in a wordpress instance outside our datacenter != an rce in python code we wrote inside ubers production network. 

>Instead of introducing these unwritten rules afterwards
The thing here is, none of these are "rules". We intend one thing and do our best to communicate it, then as exceptions occur (like this) we will update our language to better communicate the meaning. 

I appreciate your cordial communication, your hard work and good issues and your well written report. We aim to be fair but believe we have fairly valued the issue you reported based on the scope. As a general bit of advice focusing on the main web properties and uber apps themselves is the best place to find the issues we are able to reward the most.
Ive actually updated the page now to make this more clear, thank you for voicing your concerns so we can make this better for everyone

The page still claims

> Critical issues ($10,000) - Remote code execution on a production server. 

How is this ambiguous? I think most researchers would take this to mean that RCE on a production server would be rewarded with $10,000, not $2000 or zero. It still seems very problematic to me to persuade researchers to invest their time based on such blatantly misleading promises. If your page had reflected your actual policies, and said something like

> Critical issues ($10,000 or $2,000 or maybe nothing) - Remote code execution on a production server

then I, for one, would not have done two weeks of full-time work for you.

In another report #125441 you said the "our policy previously didn't make it clear the the stated amounts were maximums" and therefore you paid the bounty in accordance what was actually stated on the page. It's puzzling why you've reversed your position on this already admitted oversight. Now it seems the researchers working for you are responsible for your mistake and should only blame themselves for believing what the page says.

Well, at least the amendments now say the sums are maximums. It's a rather big difference between saying "we will pay $10,000" and "we may pay something between 0 and $10,000". It's unfortunate that this distinction wasn't seen important enough to mention until weeks later, when most research work was already done.

In my opinion also the unmentioned policy of rewarding only one bug per software package should be made clear. It's reasonable to let researchers know that after finding one bug, they're basically wasting their time and working for free instead of getting compensated in accordance with the stated policy.

Looking through your reports you have reported 9 issues. All 9 are in wordpress blogs or plugins. 

To best use your time I would encourage you to read https://eng.uber.com/bug-bounty/ and instead look in those areas, not in wordpress. To my best knowledge (and hope) all wordpress instances are run outside of uber and thus dont have access to much, if any, sensitive data. Being outside the datacenter they cannot interact with any backend systems either. This was intentional, because of the history of wordpress and associated plugins we wanted to keep them safely away if possible. 

As such issues in/around wordpress have much less of an impact on core uber. As such they will likely always be rewarded commensurately lower.

To be exact, bug #125202 (uber.com XSS) has nothing to do with WordPress. I reported 14 Uber issues some of which affect more than one site (#125469 contains 5 separate bugs, of which 2 were confirmed and 3rd looks certain).

Uber has chosen to use WordPress extensively. A quick google search finds at least 8 *.uber.com WordPress sites. If your most used CMS technology really is subject to reduced bounties or totally exempt from the program, then it's amazing you only tell it afterwards in private. The page didn't have a single word suggesting this.

The page also didn't mention anything about data centers, nor the practice of merging several bugs of different types to one "with regard to reward". This last point in particular is something I haven't seen in any other bounty program (during my about 15 years or participation).

This could hardly be more at odds with what was originally stated. The "[crystal clear] (http://techcrunch.com/2016/03/22/uber-launches-bug-bounty-program-that-pays-hackers-to-find-security-issues/)" bounty specifications were supposed to be what makes Uber's program unique. After doing a lot of work based on these assurances, getting the bounties substantially reduced or removed altogether based on all kinds of previously unmentioned exceptions is quite disappointing, to put it diplomatically. There are probably many researchers working similarly based on the false statements right now.

With regards of best use for time... Uber has gone to remarkable lengths to minimize the bounties. I don't see why similar reductions and dismissals wouldn't happen with any subsequent bugs too. I'm not planning to put any more time in this program.

I am sorry to hear you will not spend time on this program but I understand.

>Uber has chosen to use WordPress extensively. A quick google search finds at least 8 *.uber.com WordPress sites. If your most used CMS technology really is subject to reduced bounties or totally exempt from the program, then it's amazing you only tell it afterwards in private. The page didn't have a single word suggesting this.

These are not "exempt form the program", they are just much less impactful. I hope you can agree with the premise that bugs are correct to be awarded based on impact and the impact of a bug in a Wordpress blog in a datacenter run by WPEngine is less impactful than the equivalent bug in an Uber datacenter with access to Uber data and other Uber systems.

We payout what we believe an issue is worth and that is based on impact. Sometimes this means we upgrade a bug from one where the submitted didn't recognize the full impact. Other times from the outside researchers are surprised that their bug had less impact than expected, like this case.

I believe I see the core the the confusion, here is what we have had in our bug bounty page since launch:

>What is an Uber microsite?
>An Uber microsite is a website which is not explicitly listed in the scope above but is made by an Uber employee and owned by Uber. The most common examples of microsites include Uber city sites, blogs, and partner incentive sites.

>Are Uber microsites (for example, city-specific Uber sites and blogs) in scope?
>Microsites are an important part of how Uber reaches people in diverse local markets all around the world. Since they have smaller audiences, shouldn't contain much or any user data and aren’t part of the uber.com domain space, the impact of issues on these sites is significantly less severe. Since we are primary interested in vulnerabilities which could lead to the exfiltration of customer information, vulnerabilities in microsite services will not be rewarded for except in extraordinary circumstances. Generally there are better areas to spend your time than microsites.

The goal of this section was to encompass all cases, like these Wordpress cases, where the security impact of a flaw is blunted. I now realize that this part "aren’t part of the uber.com domain space" is what the problem is on this ticket. I will be changing this language to cover what you found here, microsites that happened to live under the `.uber.com` domain. When we wrote that we were using "part of the uber.com domain space" as shorthand for what should really be "access to internal Uber systems or data" which is what we were attempted to convey.

So overall I would say we attempted to make this clear but its an ongoing project to best convey what we are looking for.

> I hope you can agree with the premise that bugs are correct to be awarded based on impact ...

It would be correct to award based on your written reward policy, like happened with my first bounty.

> Other times from the outside researchers are surprised that their bug had less impact than expected, like this case.

As far as I understand, there is nothing surprising about the impact of these bugs - they're exactly what I reported from the start, "Remote code execution on a production server".

In about half of the cases your rewards aren't even impact-based but "ease-of-fixing-based" (referring to explanation at #125594). Sure, there could be 20 bugs which are easy to fix by disabling everything. It doesn't follow that impact of 19 of them was zero.

How does the hypotethical thought of 20 theoretical bugs nullify the real bugs I reported? The risk of running software containing 20 bugs is higher, not lower than with 1 bug per software. That is so unintuitive that it would have been fair to mention it.

I don't think conforming to your own written policy should be "unrealistic". **If** you think your system really has so many bugs that it's unrealistic for a multi-billion company to reward them, then launching a bounty program wasn't a good idea and clearly someone (many of them) didn't do their job. But I did, your security was substantially improved as a result, and most of my work getting dismissed as worthless is not good.

And for the record, ranting about this may seem pointless due to your [stated](http://www.valuewalk.com/2016/03/uber-bug-bounty-program/) and apparent reluctance to negotiate about the bounties. However I think it's a good thing to discuss the conventions and practices of bug bounties in general. I'm not just worried about 2 lost weeks, but the longer run. Making bounty policies consistent, predictable, and trustworthy benefits everyone and vice versa.

Since this is public I'd like to update and straighten the record a bit. It turned out WP admin scripts *could* be used to execute arbitrary server-side code despite disabled plugin/theme editing. Also, WP sites *could* be used as an entry point to the internal system at least in one case.

Both issues were demonstrated and confirmed in other reports. These were taken into account with *one* of my reports as an impact bonus. Other bounties based on the misassumption(s) remain unchanged.

In general, it doesn't seem like a harmless non-issue that an attacker can control systems used by thousands of Uber employees and perhaps millions of customers. Regarding the rationale that "there isn't **any risk** of our user data being stolen via this issue" I beg to differ.

As just one example, my cookies on drive.uber.com include my email address which I entered on one of the "core" websites. A malicious attacker with access to drive.uber.com could covertly add code that checks this cookie and if found, presents a dialog asking the user to confirm their Uber username and password. Displaying the valid email address and showing the dialog on a legitimate https-protected uber.com website would make the success rate relatively high.

Or, an exact replica of the OneLogin dialog could be displayed to Uber employees logging on drive.uber.com, saying login failed or expired (username/email known). The credentials could then be used to gain access to the internal system. So I would say there is at least *some* risk.
